comments.en: CoSMO (Calvino's Six Memos Ontology) is a literary criticism based ontology that expresses in a formal way the concept behind Calvino's textual interpretation.

Rights.value: This work is distributed under a Creative Commons Attribution License (http://creativecommons.org/licenses/by/3.0/).

comment.en: A realization of a single work usually in a physical form.
An abstract idea or notion
Series refers to when a figure establishes a series (through words or concepts). e.g., Abecedarian: Adorable, beautiful, charming, delightful, exciting, fantastic–you run the gamut from A to Z [1].
A concept to represent the weight, the inertia, the opacity of the world and the writing
A movement from a place or location to another in literary texts
Quality of things that have nature, aspect, appearence of fine dust and are therefore discontinuous and fragmentary.
Literary value or virtue of a literary text reached by removing weight from the structure of stories and from language.
The class of some common strategies employed by rhetorical figures
A resource that acts or has the power to act
Quality of everything that can be transformed into something else
Opposition refers to when a figure oppose two structures or concepts. e.g., Oxymoron: A wanton modesty. Proud humility.
Symmetry refers to when a figure pairs two constructions in an inverse (“mirrored”) way. e.g. Antimetabole: When the going gets tough, the tough get going.

Repetition refers to when a figure uses repetition of sounds (consonants, vowels, or syllables), words, syntax (phrases or clauses) or semantics (concepts). e.g., Rhyme–Hickory Dickory Dock. The mouse ran up the clock.
A concept that results from interpreting a literary text
The visual luminosity expressed in a literary text
Similarity (partial-identity) refers to when a figure uses resemblance of a concept. e.g., Simile: My love is like a red, red rose.
An imaginary person represented in a work of literary fiction
A living or dead individual
This class defines the concepts involved when interpreting a literary text
A textual expression of a work of literature
A lack of physical or literary motion as represented in literary texts
Absence of light
Omission refers to when a figure omits expected elements. e.g., Asyndeton (which omits the expected conjunction, “and”): I came, I saw, I conquered.

comment.undefined: Identity refers to when a figure uses two or more identical elements. e.g., Ploce: O villain, villain, smiling, damned villain!(Hamlet [5]).

comment.en: Quality of things that are put on the same level
The inability to act as expressed in literary texts
A name given to the resource
This property relates a text with an interpreted concept recognised by Calvino's as a value or virtue of literature.
Relates a concept or agent to a text that includes their textual string reference
This property states that lightness is related to heaviness because of a subtraction of weight.
An entity primarily responsible for making the resource.
This property states that heaviness is absence of lightness.
Relates a rhetorical figure to a specific line of the textual reference
Relates a fictional character to the interpreted concept that it symbolizes
This property relates a fictional character or interpretation to the text where it comes from.
This property relates a rhetorical figure with a particular literary text in which it is present.
This property relates a rhetorical figure to an interpreted concept. E.g. a period that expresses mutability could be constructed using anaphora.
This property shows when lightness is absent from a particular literary text.
This property relates a particular literary text with a fictional character that is present in it.
This property relates a literary text with lightness through a connection stating that the text lacks of lightness
This property describes the relation between heaviness and mutability since the latter is what changes heaviness into lightness.
This property relates a fictional character that is present in a particular literary text.
This property relates an interpreted concept recognised by Calvino's as a value or virtue of literature with a particular literary text.
This property relates a literary text with a fictional character that is mentioned inside the narrative of that text
This property relates an interpreted concept to a rhetorical figure.
Relates a concept or agent to a fragment that includes their textual string reference
This property relates an interpreted concept to a fictional character that represents it.
This property indicates the lightening force of mutability upon the category of heaviness.
This property relates a literary text that contains a rhetorical figure.
This property states the opposition between heaviness and lightness
